Editorial Publications Study
For more than 20 years the NAEB has published a monthly News-
letter. This publication has progressed from a single page, mimeographed
* ‘family letter*' to a printed, professionally-edited publication enjoying
a good reputation both within and without the educational broadcasting
field. NAEB officials are frequently surprised at the extent to which
this publication is excerpted by the broadcasting publications of other
nations,
At the time of the merger of the Association for Education by
Radio-Television and the NAEB, the NAEB assumed publication of the
former AERT Journal, which has since become the NAEB Tournai. At that
time several important decisions had to be made about whether or not to
continue both publications, what should be the scope and editorial
policy of each, etc. It was felt that the only way in which valid deci¬
sions could be reached was to employ, as consultants, qualified spec~
ialists to bring in recommendations based both on a study of these pub¬
lications and other related publications in the nation.
For this purpose a grant of $2,000 was received from the Ford
Foundation in 1956, and the study was made by a committee of three
journalism faculty members at the University of Illinois, who do such
